awd_titl_txt: Supporting and Providing Access for Deaf Students in Signed Language Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the diversification of researchers who work on signed languages and their communities of users. Historically, the majority of signed language researchers have been hearing people, most of whom are adult learners of a signed language. However, there are few deaf and hard of hearing (hereafter deaf) signers among the ranks of signed language researchers. This project uses a mentorship model to provide a small group of deaf college and university students from throughout the United States with professional-development activities and support for attending the international Theoretical Issues in Sign Language Research (TISLR) conference. TISLR is the premier conference for signed language research in the world. The aim is to provide key opportunities for deaf students from the United States that will support their progression in graduate work and future involvement in the field of signed language research.

The project will accomplish its goals in two key ways. First, deaf students who are chosen (via rigorous application process) to be part of pre- and post-conference mentorship activities will meet virtually with current deaf researchers, to discuss methods for engaging in academic research, presenting one’s findings at conferences, publishing the results of one’s work in scholarly journals, and engaging with the deaf community in order to share research findings and promote future recruitment of deaf students to the field. Second, deaf students will attend the TISLR conference (either in person or virtually), supported by American Sign Language-English interpretation services. The interpretation services are crucial because many conference presentations and activities will occur in (oral) English. Interpretation support will allow the deaf candidates supported by the project to access oral language and engage fully with the conference program and with other researchers in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The "Supporting and Providing Access for Deaf Students in Signed Language Research" project (funded by the National Science Foundation, NSF) provided mentorship experiences to nine deaf university students and supported their in-person or virtual attendance at Theoretical Issues in Sign Language Research (TISLR), the premier conference on signed language research. TISLR14 was held in Osaka, Japan in September of 2022. In order to have access to the conference program, the students were also provided with ASL-English interpretation services. Six established researchers (who are also deaf) served as mentors to the nine deaf students.

 

The overall goal of the project was to support the academic and professional development of future deaf researchers, with a focus on linguistics and language science. Even though many deaf individuals are daily users of one or more signed language, there are very few deaf researchers in the field of linguistics. The field could benefit greatly from the expertise, insight, and knowledge of deaf daily users of signed language who are trained in language science techniques.

 

Because of COVID concerns, only six students elected to attend TISLR14 in person, and three attended virtually by traveling to Gallaudet University in Washington DC and viewing the conference talks with other students and faculty of Gallaudet University. The project included a pre-conference meeting (via zoom) with students, which was followed by one-on-one discussions between deaf mentors (all deaf PhD researchers at universities throughout the country) and the students. The virtual experience at Gallaudet can be likened to a local workshop where participants - members of Gallaudet University who registered for the conference as well as the NSF-sponsored students - came together all week to co-watch the virtual TISLR14 live-streaming/pre-recorded presentations or virtual poster sessions. Outside of the TISLR presentations, the virtual attendees participated in face-to-face live discussions at Gallaudet University.

 

Mentor-mentee relationships between the six mentors and nine students were designed to be tailored the students and their interests. Students completed a questionnaire about their academic and professional interests and goals, and based on that information they were matched with mentors with overlapping interests. Sessions between mentors and mentees were diverse, and they covered topics such as academic conferences and presentations, professional development, and developing a social media presence, as appropriate. These are only some examples, since topics varied depending on individual interests of the students.

 

The support of nine deaf students from throughout the US has allowed those students to have an experience (attendance at TISLR and mentorship activities) that they otherwise might not have had access to. This experience provided exposure to the linguistics of signed language, including detailed exposure to various sub-fields of signed language linguistics (since TISLR is a generalist conference), including traditional areas of linguistics (phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, etc.), sociolinguistics, and applied areas (e.g. language teaching, interpretation, etc.). This involvement is expected to inform the students’ future trajectories, especially with respect to other forms of graduate and professional training. The experience has allowed these students to gain a unique perspective about linguistic research on signed languages, which will influence their own future work and how they interact with others about this topic. Several remarked on how the conference experience was eye-opening in many ways - in how deaf or signing people navigate language experiences in international settings, how researchers communicate about academic topics and network, and how deaf people have a place in academia. One deaf student even remarked that they decided to stay in linguistics solely because of this experience - they were on the brink of quitting their linguistics program when they attended the conference with the support of this grant. The involvement of deaf mentors, an underrepresented group, has allowed these individuals to contribute to the development of more deaf researchers in linguistics and related fields.
